Dec 8/15 

8.30 am writing this by aid of an inch of candle in an old mess hut.

We are to move off in a couple of hours to the Railway. There will be no sleep tonight as by the time we get to the station 
it will
 & load up horses & waggons on the train it will be 4 a.m. 

We have a great camp fire roaring outside built up of old boxes & the accumulation of months of camp. The men are all sat round

smoking & it 
gives
 is just one of those occassional touches of glamour of which there is to little in modern war. There promises to be a ‘dry’ journey in front of us as each waggon has been issued with an 8 gallon water bag. One knows absolutely nothing definite of what is ahead yet one doesn’t worry – one has become accustomed to being a cog in a big machine – which is set in motion by someone & sets it rolling & working in its proper direction.

As soon as 
of
 news of this move got about, 
men came
 its wonderful the cures that were made in some of our sick in the hospitals & convalescent Homes! Two

more have just come in this last minute. One of them Cpl ‘Dick’ Dawson – with no kit at all but his simple uniform, not even great coat – but guess’ll he ‘pick’ one up as he goes on.

Dec 12/15 

Havn’t had a single minute to call my own since last entry, except those required for sleep – am now writing this on the box seat of a waggon by candlelight at 11.45 pm while on horsepicket 

am on duty from 10 p.m. until 1.30 and was up at 4.30 this morning & have to be up tomorrow at the same hour. Will never forget the last 
few
 3 days – since leaving the rail head – a little name on the map only containing a mosque, a well &

a very small garrison of camel corps – we have been pushing across the desert on our trek to Matrugh, a journey of 85 miles from waterhole to waterhole – 

I think
 I have been thirsty before but think for the first time of my life I have known what it was "to thirst" for what water there 
has
 is 
been
 has been 
most unpal
 only fit after boiling & even then as tea most unpalatable & in ordinary sense undrinkable – 
It was in
 In Kiplings words it was "green & stunk". But it is not nearly so bad for 
the men
 us as for the horses – we know it is for a common cause & 
must
 cannot be helped – but it 
is
 nearly makes one weep to see the 

flagging horses & to 
kn
 have to drive them on knowing that it will be hours before they can be rested & the only thing to do is to get them there. 

We watered our horses yesterday at a brackish well 
close to
 practically on the sea beach So salt the horses although parched would hardly drink it – That was yesterday midday 

covered 12 miles yesterday afternoon & evening & made laager for the night at 7 p.m. no water for horses, 
 up at 4.30 this morning & left camp at 6 p.m. & forced the poor
 so dry that they would hardly 
indecipherable
 eat at all. Up at 4.30 a.m. this morning & left camp at 

6 p.m. (?) & have been slogging along all day without any drink for the horses – in the 12 hours today we have covered about 22 miles – many horses absolutely ‘pulled right out" & an occasional gallon of water had to be given them out of our emergency ration to keep them going. 

But Thank God after 36 hours without watering & covering 32 miles on a bad desert track very heavy going – we have reached a good waterhole & I though they would never stop dinking all had a good feed of 
corn
 barley & bran & little chaff & they are very quiet now

While we halted at midday 2 armoured cars of the RNAS Cars 

passed the convoy & told us there was a fight last night near Matrugh & we had 16 killed & 30 wounded So far we have seen no sign of the enemy we travel with a small escort of yeomanry scouts out all round

Told by my
 We are camped with waggons drawn up in a square & all horse inside & have to sleep with rifle & bandoliers alongside us I was told by our O.C. that there is a force of about 500 Bedouin somewhere between us & Matrugh whether they will attempt to attack us or not is for the future

The sunsets across the desert are a mass of warm colour & as we are tracking west – it is a lovely yet rather melancholy sight to look ahead & see the long column of waggons 
waggon teams
 & dust winding into the distance with the last rays of the sun upon them One has to feel both tired & hungry to appreciate 
the
 & feel the glamour of the sight. In fact so hungry as to look forward with pleasant 
art
 anticipation to a tin of bully, hard biscuit & a pannikin of ‘Gunga Din’ Tea 

We have our funny moments however, 
when
 we were having

a midday halt for half an hour 
when the
 drawn up in 2 lines on either side of the track when the 2 RNAS cars passed us & we saw them coming down the track a long way off. Some of the moving spirits started making a ‘Race meeting’ of it & we all mounted on top of the waggons while the Regimental comedians Roared out the Racing ‘patter’. 
Don’t know what the English officers thought of us.

People
 Everyone says

days

 the furniture, clothing etc strewn all over the place but a guard is all round now & there is no chance of picking up any ‘souvenirs’.

Yesterday a regiment of our Light Horse went out reconnoitring & got in touch

our casual

Today a party of friendly natives were brought in Except for the soldiers

 liked to have got a photo

of course I don’t know how

Entry.11:
25/15 

There has been quite a small battle round here today – woke up from sleep during the night by the sound of firing by some of our outposts in the block houses on the hill – also by the ‘ping’ of several responding bullets over
he
 our heads 
Heard
 Time was 10 to 1. so we wished each other a Merry Xmas Sgt. Moore got into his breeches anticipating a general "fall=in". The rest of us sat up in our blankets

but finding the night air cold decided before taking any strong measures like that to wait for orders – so got down in our blankets again & went to sleep. At daybreak our ALH & a Regt of Yeomanry moved out with some 
of our
 AASC wagons they went west along the coast road. About 8 o’clock I heard big gun fire for the first time since Gallipoli in June – It was our cruiser along the coast giving the Bedouin some "hurry up"

A few details came filtering through with the arrivals of some wounded who were brought in by motor ambulance the first arriving about 2 pm. Chiefly Sikh Infantry then 
two

or 3
 several of our L.H & Yeomanry were brought in 
followed by some Y

From accounts our troops were steadily sweeping them down the road – the guns from the 2 cruiser following them as they retreated. About 4 p.m. 6 Indian Prisoners who had escaped were brought in & after being questioned by the General joined their friend & a great "corroboree" was held – An Interpreter told us that they are part of the few survivors of a transport bound for France that was wrecked or torpedoed off the Tripoli Coast – The survivors Indian soldiers & a few white officers got to the coast - & were taken prisoners by the Bedouins

The whitemen had been sent into the interior but the Indians were kept digging trenches etc & this party of 6 were in a trench which was shelled by a warship The Bedouin fled so the Indians took their chance & ran towards our men crying "Indian – Ingleese". They’d had a rough time living in daily fear of having their 
coats
 throats cut any minute & fed on a handful of dried peas daily & clad in sacking.

Things have been very busy this last few days runing barbed wire right round the camp – & digging rifle trenches behind them – The few tents outside 
hav
 the barbed wire have been lowered tonight & the waggons brought

inside & formed up in a 
solid
 long line – tailboard of one up to the rear of the next one Just a last precautionary measure I suppose whether they will be needed or not remain to be seen.

All the spare men of our Coy have been sent up to form an inlying picket behind the front trenches

Entry.17:
12/16 

The Light Horse Regt have left this morning – they are returning to the railhead (el Dabaa) & thence by rail to Cairo to rejoin their various regiments from which they were drawn to make up this Comp. Regt. – As far as is known in the ranks their various regiments will be moving 
shortly
 down soon to the Canal where there seems to be big trouble coming. 
All the Divis
 A squadron of them are left behind & are to follow in a week

All the Divisional Train waggons have gone with them carrying forage – supplies & water & I expect will stop at el Dabaa & then return with the Complete

 
Unit
 Regt which will possibly be coming to take their place

It hurt to see my Company 
be lef
 move off & be left behind in Camp, their is nothing finer than the joy of being on the trek however hard it is. And I had the ‘pip’ all morning.

I put in a written application to the O.C. asking to be allowed to rejoin my company for ordinary duty but so far have had no reply.

Jack Stanton the L.H. Postal orderly also was ‘fed up’ as we have had nothing to do all day, so this afternoon we went up to the L.H Lines & borrowed a couple of horses & have been for a good ride & gallop round the Camp and on the beach

They were good horses 
and we had to hang on
 pulling on the bit to be off all the time & I came back from the ride as 
pleasan
 hungry as a hunter. with the ‘pip’ gone for the time

Everything seems very quiet now The shaking up they got on Xmas Day seems to have take all the sting out of the enemy & I don’t think there will be much more serious trouble, though I expect a force will be kept here for some time.

Have been passing
 My best pals are all away on the trek, so instead of yarning in their tent – Ive been smoking on my own & read Kiplings "Five nations" sent me by Edie & Mop (Sisters) for Xmas.

"Ah God one sniff of England

To greet my flesh & blood

To see the hansoms slurring

Once more through London Mud"
Entry.18:
– (I think) 

Hurrah, have got out of that Postal orderly job and am back again for duty with my Company. 
It was a bit difficult getting away &
 It means harder work & none of the "sweets of office" in the way of soft living but it is more satisfactory to be back with the Company with which I started with. 

This diary seems to be dying a natural death, but nothing seems to have happened worth recording. We got some new arrivals last night in the shape of 180 men & 5 officers from the South African

Contingent that went home to England. I suppose most of them will find their way out here, as France will be too cold for them

There is a rumour to the effect that we are to return to join up with the
Entry.19:
Division to which we belong & which is now down near the Canal

The enemy have started gathering again in force near the wells from which they were dispersed on Xmas Day – so I expect another column will be sent out in a day or two to deal with them.
Entry.20:
Orders came out this morning of a column leaving camp this afternoon to attack the enemy & all our waggons available had to turn out. 
Just
 As I’m just

back on the lines & have not been allotted a team, I’m a spare Driver at present with only one horse that is rather out of condition & is having a rest, but would do to go in harness if necessary.

I hadn’t been told to go, but I hadn’t been told not to, so I quietly put my blankets in a waggon, saddled up my horse & kept out of the way until just about time to move off, hoping I’d be overlooked only to find that every other spare man had done the same! 

They dragged us all out & asked us "What the How the" etc 

The Captain said "You carry on as though you were at

a something picnic". At anyrate we were all left behind as extra mouths to feed & not required.

Saw the column move out & were specially interested in the South Africans, a battalion of whom arrived a couple of days ago from England where they had been finishing there training. They are a fine lot physically quite distinct facially to the 
Aust
 Anzac Soldier, seem to be much fuller & flatter faced, evidently a big strain of Dutch blood in them. 
This was
 A number of them had been in S.W. Africa but as a battalion this was their first time of going into action & they looked very eager for it.

They gave us their war cry as they passed – a sort of Zulu Chant 
which would have a very
 which sounded very blood curdling.
Entry.21:
Yesterday Sunday was on outpost duty all day in a Sangar (Block house) just a round wall of stone surmounted with sandbags & loopholes surrounded by barb wire. There were 3 of us & a 
Cap
 Corporal also two Signallers of the Royal Scots (who hailed from Manchester bye the bye) these two were in charge of the telegraph line & keyboard which connected us up with the Headquarters – we were on the left flank of the ring of hills which surround the camp

Far below & behind us was a grand panorama of the Camp, the Village & the Harbour, while in front was a stony sandy plain quite flat for miles & in the distance some more low hills we never saw a living thing stirring all day. A message came along that the column got in touch with the enemy late in the afternoon. 

We were relieved at 6.30 pm by the night picket – 20 men & a Sergeant – All today we have been "standing by" not a very exciting share in a battle Several motor ambulance loads of wounded have come in, and some more waggons left this afternoon with supplies & I expected to be 

one of the escort, was "told off" & was getting ready when the orders were changed & No 4 Coy had to supply the escort instead
Entry.22:
24/16 (Tuesday) 

The Column came back this afternoon, from all accounts the honours seem to be even between us & the enemy Our total casualties of killed & wounded being just under 300. The bulk of these are with the Sikhs & the S Africans 

I saw the latter march in. – There were hardly half the battalion in the body the rest came straggling in leg weary 
footsore
 & foot & blistered, or were riding in on the A.S.C. Waggons dead beat

They fought well but the heavy marching had been too much for them coming straight into it soft from a sea trip. 
The

Our chaps have had a heavy time of it – the Roads were very soft & the waggons getting bogged continually – so it was a case of pulling each other out by turns consequently there were G.S. Waggons all over the countryside, in addition to bogged Motor Cars & other vehicles. If the roads had been better so as the armoured cars could have joined in, the engagement would have been more decisive

As it is 
there
 we have inflicted heavy casualties on the enemy & driven them away from the wells, but as they can reoccupy them at any 
rate
 time & also inflicted serious casualties on us it seems to be a stalemate

The weather 
is
 has been miserable today

a bitterly cold wind blowing the sand up all the time which one can feel 
like
 across one’s face like the cut of a whip lash.
Entry.23:
The aeroplane had an accident at noon today on its return from its daily patrol. Was watching it while watering my horse & just as it was 30 or 40 feet of the ground it fell ‘head first’, 
just
 on the beach within a few feet of the water – Luckily both aviator & observer were only severely shaken & were able to walk to the ambulance which took them to hospital to be attended to
Entry.24:
Have received orders to start

tomorrow to Alexandria & from there we understand to the Canal – only Right half of No 1 Coy & No 4 Coy. 

The left half of No 1 Coy which is at Dabaa is coming to take our place.

Busy all day packing stores & forage for our 5 days trek back
Entry.25:
We moved out of Matruh about 9 am. In addition to the AASC mentioned above we have an escort of one Company of Middesex Infantry about 50 L.H. & the same number of Yeomanry 

The road was in good condition & we
 We are also taking along a mob of 
captured
 camels. The road was 

 in condition & we made good time arriving at Jerrawalla Well – our halting place by 2 o’clock, watered & fed our horses & then had dinner (tea, biscuits & bully & jam) groomed our horses this afternoon, while we were doing this two armoured car "patrols came up & they brought us some mail which was very welcome. I got 5 letters & a book "Many Inventions" from Amy (Hargreaves) 

Am writing this by candlelight alongside the wagon at 6.30 pm. & am now going to turn in as I expect it will be 4.30 reveille
Entry.26:
6 p.m. – 

We travelled 18 miles yesterday – good going the whole way except through a place where the road dipped sharply and after the heavy rains was very soft & most of the

waggons got ‘bogged’ & had to have extra horses hitched on to drag them through.

The Camels we are bringing along with us belong to the Sheikh of Bershola a loyal Senoussi – we started off with 90 odd but yesterday morning we found only 11 left – the rest had strayed away during the night. 
We had
 A bit of a loss for him as we couldn’t waste time hunting for them. He is coming through to el Dabba with us – with two young wives & a baby in arms – all riding on one of the waggons – he is quite a young man

Last night we camp at el Gerboosh (that is

how it is pronounced) it was the scene of a very bloody battle between the Italians & the Senoussi in the last Italy-Turkey War. 

We left at 9 oclock this
 

The transport who are going up to take our place at Matruh were also camped there. We left at 9 this morning and are camping this evening after an easy 1,6 miles at a small well by the road side
Entry.27:
Have done about 20 miles today & are camped near a small waterhole The roads are good after the recent rains – and also the water is better & more plentiful so it

is a much easier trip than when we went to Matruh, where it was after sundown pretty well every evening before we ‘parked’ the waggons

We have just ‘dined’ bully beef, jam, cheese biscuits tea & also 
some
 a billy can full of biscuit porridge which we have made over a little fire. Just Biscuits broken up small & boiled up in water till soft then eaten hot with plenty of sugar. It eats very good at the end of a day or early morning but sounds rather primitive no doubt.

We passed several native huts & I had a look inside for a "souvenirs" but they had been stripped

bare and the roofs (the only thing about them imflamable) had been burnt off.

They didn’t expect us to find water at our present bivouac and had arranged for a supply to come out by camel & a column of about 100 camels has just come in – carrying water for our horses. It is camped just alongside us.

El Dabaa our destination is about 20 miles on so we should reach it easily tomorrow afternoon
Entry.28:
El Dabaa arrived here yesterday 
the
 at 1.30 p.m. Soon after leaving the camp we picked up 
the
 our infantry escort & carried them along on the

waggons & thus were able to press on & get here to the Railhead in good time 

we are bivouaced alongside the railway waiting orders to entrain
